{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox country demographics | country = Nauru | image = Population of Nauru.svg | caption = Scatter plot of the population of Nauru, 1886–2011 | size_of_population = 10,084 (2011) | density = 478 / sq km. (2011)
185 / sq mi. | growth = 0.19% (2002{{ndash}}11) | birth = 27.20 (2007{{ndash}}11) | death = 7.50 (2007{{ndash}}11) | life = 59.7 (2011) | life_male = 56.8 (2011) | life_female = 62.7 (2011) | infant_mortality = 44.0 (2011) | fertility = 3.70 (2009–11) | net_migration = 84 (2009) | age_0–14_years = 32.5% (2014 {{abbr|est.|estimate}}) | age_15–64_years = 65.6% (2014 {{abbr|est.|estimate}}) | age_65_years = 1.8% (2014 {{abbr|est.|estimate}}) | total_mf_ratio = 0.91 males/female (2014 {{abbr|est.|estimate}}) | sr_at_birth = 0.84 males/female (2014 {{abbr|est.|estimate}}) | sr_under_15 = 0.79 males/female (2014 {{abbr|est.|estimate}}) | sr_15–64_years = 1.00 males/female (2014 {{abbr|est.|estimate}}) | sr_65_years_over = 0.78 males/female (2014 {{abbr|est.|estimate}}) | nation = ''noun'' Nauruan(s), ''adj.'' Nauruan | major_ethnic = Nauruan (93.6%) | minor_ethnic = Chinese (1.5%), I-Kiribati (1.8%) | official = Nauruan | spoken = English }} The '''demographics of [[Nauru]]''', an [[island country]] in the [[Pacific Ocean]], are known through national [[census]]es, which have been analysed by various statistical bureaus since the 1920s. The [[Nauru Bureau of Statistics]] have conducted this task since 1977—the first census since Nauru gained independence in 1968. The most recent census of Nauru was in 2011, when population had reached ten thousand. The population density is 478 inhabitants per square kilometre (185 per square mile), and the overall [[life expectancy]] is 59.7 years. The population rose steadily from the 1960s until 2006 when the Government of Nauru repatriated thousands of Tuvaluan and [[I-Kiribati]] workers from the country. Since 1992, Nauru's [[birth rate]] has exceeded its [[death rate]]; the natural growth rate is positive. In terms of age structure, the population is dominated by the 15–64-year-old segment (65.6%). The median age of the population is 21.5, and the estimated gender ratio of the population is 0.91 males per one female. Nauru is inhabited mostly by [[Nauruan people|Nauruans]] (93.6%), while minorities include I-Kiribati (1.8%), Chinese (1.5%) and other (3.1%). The demographic history of Nauru is marked by several migrations: the area was first inhabited by Micronesian people about 3,000 years ago. The first European to find the island was [[John Fearn (whaler)|John Fearn]] in 1798. Then, the country was annexed by Germany in the 1888. The next was when Japanese occupied the island during [[World War II]] in the 1942. During this time, the Japanese deported several thousands of Nauruans to other islands. In the 1960s, the country gained independence, where the percentage of Nauruans started to increase. The most recent demographic switch was in the 2000s, when the government repatriated several non-Nauruan population from the country. The [[Nauruan language]] is the official language of Nauru, but English is often used in the country. Nauruan is declared as the primary language of 95.3% of the population. The 2011 census revealed that 66.0% of the population spoke English and 11.9% another language. The main religions of Nauru are [[Nauru Congregational Church]] (35.71%) and [[Roman Catholic]] (32.96%). The [[literacy rate]] in Nauru is 96.5%. The proportion of the country's population aged 15 and over attaining [[academic degrees]] is one of the lowest in the world, reaching 7.9% in 2011. An estimated 10.7% of the gross domestic product (GDP) is spent on education. Nauru has a [[universal health care]] system, and in 2012, an estimated 7.5% of its GDP was spent on healthcare. Nauru has the highest [[obesity]] ranking in the world; 97 per cent of men and 93 per cent of women are obese. In 2006, the average net monthly income was [[Australian dollar|A$]]2,597 (A${{Inflation|AU|2597|2006|r=0}} in 2014). The most significant sources of employment are [[Phosphate mining in Nauru|phosphate mining]], banking industries, and various [[coconut]] products. In 2011, the [[unemployment rate]] was 23%. The 2011 census enumerated 1,647 total households, averaging 6.0 persons per house. Average [[Urbanization|urbanisation rate]] in Nauru is 100%. == Population == {{Historical populations |title = Historical population of Nauru |align = right |percentages = pagr |footnote = 1 Estimate |source = The Centre for Independent Studies,{{Harvnb|Hughes|2004|p=2}} Nauru Bureau of Statistics{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2011|p=7}} |1886 |1294 |1921 |2066 |1933 |2641 |1947 |2855 |1954 |3473 |1961 |4613 |1966 |6057 |1977 |6966 |1983 |7674 |1992 |9919 |2002 |10065 |2006 |9233 |2011 |10084 |20131|10293 }} With a population of ten thousand in 2011, Nauru [[List of countries by population|ranks around 230th in the world by population]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/ |title=Nauru Stats at a Glance |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RVPKBudl?url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/ |archivedate=1 August 2014 |publisher=Nauru Bureau of Statistics |accessdate=1 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Its population density is 478 inhabitants per square kilometre (185 per square mile). The overall [[List of countries by life expectancy|life expectancy]] in Nauru at birth is 59.7 years. The [[total fertility rate]] of 3.70 children per mother is one of the [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories by fertility rate|highest in the Oceania]]. The United Nations projects the population will stay around 10,000 in the 2020s,{{cite web|url=http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/unpp/panel_population.htm |title=Population |work=World Population Prospectus |publisher=United Nations |year=2012 |accessdate=6 August 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RcHhdXBF?url=http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/unpp/panel_population.htm |archivedate=6 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} and the Nauru Bureau of Statistics estimates the population will increase to 20,000 in 2038.{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2011|p=164}} In Nauru's history, there have been six major demographics changes. The island was first inhabited by Micronesian people roughly 3,000 years ago.{{Cite report | url=http://www.unccd.int/cop/reports/asia/national/2002/nauru-eng.pdf | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722013720/http://www.unccd.int/cop/reports/asia/national/2002/nauru-eng.pdf | archivedate=22 July 2011 | title=First National Report to the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD): Nauru | publisher=United Nations | year=2003 | accessdate=29 June 2014 | page=11}} The first European to find the island was [[John Fearn (whaler)|John Fearn]] in 1798. In 1888, the country was annexed by Germany. The next demographic change came when [[Japanese occupation of Nauru|Japanese occupied the island]] during [[World War II]] in the 1940s.{{Cite news|last=Shenon |first=Philip |date=10 December 1995 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/world/a-pacific-island-nation-is-stripped-of-everything.html |title=A Pacific Island Nation is Stripped of Everything |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=6 August 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RcHlJfEu?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/world/a-pacific-island-nation-is-stripped-of-everything.html |archivedate=6 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} During this time, the Japanese deported several thousands of Nauruans to other islands.{{Cite journal | last=Bogart | first=Charles | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012031555/http://cdsg.org/reprint%20PDFs/CDSGNnov08.pdf | archivedate=12 October 2013 | url=http://cdsg.org/reprint%20PDFs/CDSGNnov08.pdf | title=Death Off Nauru | magazine=The CDS Newsletter | publisher=The Coast Defense Study Group | year=2008 | accessdate=17 July 2014}} The next major demographic change was in the 1960s; the country gained independence, where the percentage of Nauruans started to increase.{{Cite journal | last=Davidson | first=JW | year=2008 | title=The Republic of Nauru | journal=[[The Journal of Pacific History]] | pages=145–150 | volume=3 | issue=1 | doi=10.1080/00223346808572131}} The last major demographics change was in 2006 when the Government of Nauru repatriated almost all of the remaining [[Tuvaluan people|Tuvaluan]] and [[I-Kiribati]] workers, following large scale reduction from the [[Nauru Phosphate Corporation|Republic of Nauru Phosphate Corporation]] (RONPhos) and government workers.{{Cite report | ref=harv | author=Asian Development Bank | url=http://www.adb.org/Documents/CERs/NAU/CER-NAU-2007.pdf | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607064452/http://www.adb.org/Documents/CERs/NAU/CER-NAU-2007.pdf | archivedate=7 June 2011 | title=Country Economic Report: Nauru | publisher=[[Asian Development Bank]] | accessdate=29 June 2014 | year=2007 | pp=2–3}} The census of 2006 stated 9,233 people were in Nauru: down 2.13% per year from the previous census of 2002. From 2002–11, there has been negative net migration, with an annual 109 net emigrants from 2006–11.{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2011|p=50}} In 2009 there were 1,820 arrivals and 1,736 departures, for a positive rate of 84 immigrants. This was the first time since collecting data in 2002, there was a positive rate. Data on arrivals and departures collected by the Nauruan Customs and Immigration Office is not available, so specific immigration data is unavailable.{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2011|p=48}} As of the 2011 census, 57% of the population over 15 years old were legally or ''de facto'' married, 35% were never married, while 7% were either widowed, separated, or divorced.{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2011|p=52}} There are 1,647 households in Nauru, making an average household size of 6.0 persons per household.{{cite web | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/index.php/population-censuses | title=Population Census of 2011 | publisher=[[Nauru Bureau of Statistics]] | accessdate=29 June 2014}} == Vital statistics == For births, deaths, and fertility rates, the Nauru Bureau of Statistics was used.{{cite web | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=190&Itemid=265#births-summary | title=Vital Statistics – Births/Fertility | publisher=[[Nauru Bureau of Statistics]] | accessdate=14 July 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=189&Itemid=266#mortality-summary | title=Vital Statistics – Deaths/Mortality | publisher=[[Nauru Bureau of Statistics]] | accessdate=14 July 2014}}{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2002|p=94}} For population, the [[United States Census Bureau]]'s mid-year estimated were used.{{cite web | url=https://www.census.gov/population/international/data/idb/region.php?N=Results&T=6&A=separate&RT=0&Y=1992,1993,1994,1995,1996,1997,1998,1999,2000,2001,2002,2003,2004,2005,2006,2007,2008,2009,2010,2011,2012,2013&R=-1&C=NR | title=Midyear Population and Density – Custom Region – Nauru | publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]] | accessdate=25 July 2014}} If a cell is shaded light green and a dagger{{Dagger}} stands |publisher=Theodora.com |date= |accessdate=29 July 2014}} In 2013, the number of births (366) and birth rate (38.8) was the second-highest during this period. In 2011, the total fertility rate of 4.2 was the highest since 1992 (4.5). scope="col" | 2013 | 9,434 | 366 | {{NA}} | {{NA}} | {{Decimals|38.795844816620733517065931736273|1}} | {{NA}} | {{NA}} | {{NA}} |} == Ethnic groups == Nauru, as of 2011, is mainly inhabited by [[Nauruan people|Nauruan]]s (94%), while the main minority groups include [[Fijians]] (1%), Chinese (1%), and [[Solomon Island]]ers (1%). This shows a major change from the previous major census of 2002, when Nauruans represented 75% of the population.{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2011|p=83}} According to the Constitution Nauru does not exclude any ethnic group to become a citizen. {|class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" rowspan="2" | Ethnic group ! scope="col" colspan="2" | 2011 ! scope="col" colspan="2" | 2006 ! scope="col" colspan="2" | 2002 |- ! scope="col" | Number ! scope="col" | % ! scope="col" | Number ! scope="col" | % ! scope="col" | Number ! scope="col" | % |- ! scope="row" | Nauruan | 9,313 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 9313/9945*100}}|1}} || 9,547 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 9547/9968*100}}|1}} || 7,572 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 7572/10065*100}}|1}} |- ! scope="row" | I-Kiribati | 178 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 178/9945*100}}|1}} || 146 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 145/9968*100}}|1}} || 1,259 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 1259/10065*100}}|1}} |- ! scope="row" | Chinese | 145 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 145/9945*100}}|1}} || 61 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 61/9968*100}}|1}} || 463 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 463/10065*100}}|1}} |- ! scope="row" | Other | 309 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 309/9945*100}}|1}} || 214 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 214/9968*100}}|1}} || 771 || {{Decimals|{{#expr: 771/10065*100}}|1}} |- ! scope="row" | Total ! 9,945 !! 100 !! 9,968 !! 100 !! 10,065 !! 100 |- ! colspan="7" | Source: Nauru Bureau of Statistics{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2007|p=18}} |} == Languages == The [[Nauruan language]] is the official language of Nauru. English is widely understood and is used for most government and commercial purposes.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nr.html |title=Nauru |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RVPUjQKr?url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nr.html |archivedate=1 August 2014 |publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]] |work=[[The World Factbook]] |date=20 June 2014 |accessdate=1 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} According to the 2011 census, 95.3% of the population speaks Nauruan, 66.0% speak English, and 11.9% speak another language. Nauruan is an [[Austronesian languages|Austronesian]] language, however, no adequate written grammar of the language has been compiled, and its relationships to other Micronesian languages are not well understood.{{cite web | last=Foster | first=Sophie | date=18 November 2013 | url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/406671/Nauru#ref513887 | title=Nauru | page=1 | work=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] | accessdate=17 July 2014}} == Religions == {{Main|Religion in Nauru}} {{bar box |title=Religion in Nauru, 2011{{cite web|url= https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nr.html|title= Australia-Oceania :: NAURU|publisher= CIA The World Factbook}} |titlebar=#ddd |left1=religion |right1=percent |float=left |bars= {{bar percent|[[Nauru Congregational Church|Nauru Congregational]]|#e41a1c| 35.7}} {{bar percent|[[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]]|#377eb8|33}} {{bar percent|[[Assemblies of God]]|#4daf4a| 13}} {{bar percent|[[Nauruan indigenous religion|Nauru Independent Church]]|#984ea3|9.5}} {{bar percent|[[Baptist]]|#ff7f00|1.5}} {{bar percent|Other or not stated|#a65628|3.7}} }} The main religions in Nauru are [[Nauru Congregational Church|Nauru Congregational]] (35.71%), [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] (32.96%), [[Assemblies of God]] (12.98%), and [[Nauruan indigenous religion|Nauru Independent]] (9.50%). The biggest changes from 2002–11 were an increase from 0 to 1,291 (Assemblies of God) and 1,417 to 282 (Other). Public holidays include New Year's Day (1 January), Independence Day (31 January), Good Friday, Easter Monday, Easter Tuesday, Constitution Day (17 May), National Youth Day (25 September), Christmas Day, and Boxer Day.{{cite web | url=http://www.un.int/nauru/countryprofile.html | title=Nauru Country Profile | publisher=United Nations | accessdate=21 July 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727070348/http://www.un.int/nauru/countryprofile.html | archivedate=27 July 2013 | df=dmy-all }} Nauruan Independent was the predominant religion in Nauru before the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, when foreign missionaries introduced Christianity to the island. It is still practised by 9.5% of the population, according to 2011 census. There are a few active Christian missionary organisations, including representatives of Anglicanism, Methodism, and Catholicism. The Constitution provides for [[freedom of religion]];{{cite web | url=http://www.naurugov.nr/parliament-of-nauru/constitution-of-nauru.aspx | title=Constitution of Nauru | publisher=Nauru Government | accessdate=21 July 2014}} however, the Government restricted this right in some circumstances. The government has restricted the religious practices of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] and the [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], most of whom are foreign workers employed by RONPhos.{{cite web | url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90147.htm | title=International Religious Freedom Report 2007 | publisher=[[United States Department of State]] | accessdate=18 July 2014}} == Education == {{Main|Education in Nauru}} [[File:Nauru Secondary School after receiving its $11 million Australian-funded refurbishment, April 2010. Photo- DFAT (12046385216).jpg|thumb|left|A Nauruan secondary school, 2010]] [[Literacy rate]] in Nauru, defined as "people who are currently enrolled in school and/or have reached at least grade 5 of primary education",{{Harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2011|p=74}} is 96.5%, as of 2011. There are 3,190 students and 104 teachers, as of 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=127&Itemid=258#pre-school | title=Education Statistics | publisher=[[Nauru Bureau of Statistics]] | accessdate=14 July 2014}} The 2011 census stated 4 percent of the population aged 15 years or older have a primary education, 91 percent have a secondary education, and 5 percent have a tertiary education. Education is based on the British system, which requires attendance from 5 to 16 years old. Students spend three years at preschool, six years of primary education, and four years of secondary school. Tertiary school is not required.{{cite web|url=http://www.icde.org/projects/regulatory_frameworks_for_distance_education/country_profiles/nauru/education_system/ |title=Education System |publisher=[[International Council for Open and Distance Education]] |accessdate=14 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208035100/http://www.icde.org/projects/regulatory_frameworks_for_distance_education/country_profiles/nauru/education_system/ |archivedate=8 December 2013 |df=dmy }} An estimated 10.7 percent of the GDP was spend on education in 1999.{{cite web | url=http://www.unesco.org/education/wef/countryreports/nauru/rapport_1.html | title=Nauru Report | publisher=[[UNESCO]] | accessdate=18 July 2014}} As of 2013, there are five preschools, four primary schools, three secondary schools, and one tertiary school. The lone college, [[University of South Pacific]], opened in the 1970s via distance courses, and in 1987 a campus was built on the island. It offers accounting, management, primary education, and English studies as majors.{{cite web | url=http://www.usp.ac.fj/index.php?id=usp_nauru_home | title=USP Nauru Campus | publisher=[[University of South Pacific]] | accessdate=14 July 2014}} The education system had a near-collapse in 2000–2005. During this time, exams were not held, teachers were not paid, and schools did not have enough funding to continue. As a result, over half of the schools closed. In 2009, the [[Australian Government]] partnered with the Nauruan Department of Education to help. This agreement resulted in a 5.7% increase in students, teachers with a degree increased from 30% to 93%, and over A$11 million was used to construct a new secondary school.{{cite web|url=http://aid.dfat.gov.au/countries/pacific/nauru/Pages/initiative-education-support.aspx |title=Nauru: Education Support |publisher=[[Australian Government]] |accessdate=18 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223040056/http://aid.dfat.gov.au/countries/pacific/nauru/Pages/initiative-education-support.aspx |archivedate=23 February 2014 |df=dmy }} == Health == See [[Health in Nauru]] == Economic indicators == {{Main|Economy of Nauru}} [[File:Phosphate exports in Nauru, 1968-2001.svg|thumb|left|Phosphate exports (in millions of tonnes) in Nauru from 1968–2001.]] Net monthly income in 2006 averaged [[Australian dollar|A$]]2,597 (A${{Inflation|AU|2597|2006|fmt=c}} in 2014{{Inflation-fn|AU}}). In the same year, gross monthly income averaged A$9,554 (A${{Inflation|AU|9554|2006|fmt=c}} in 2014{{Inflation-fn|AU}}). This was calculated during the mini-census of 2006, which featured 54.4% response rate of the population.{{harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2007|pp=8–10}} The income was calculated using the following factors: first job salary, subsistence, other business income, second job salary, services to other households, benefits, house gifts consumed and received, and other income.{{harvnb|Nauru Bureau of Statistics|2007|p=8}} Compared to other countries that use the Australian dollar—Kiribati, Australia, and Tuvalu—Nauru ranks number one in terms of income.{{Ref_label|AAA|A}} Since 2013, Nauru does not have a [[minimum wage]].{{cite web | url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/220427.pdf | title=Nauru 2013 Human Rights Report | page=13 | publisher=[[United States Department of State]] | accessdate=29 July 2014}} Nauru's number of employed people has steadily risen and fallen. According to the 2011 census, there are 908 employed persons and 2,883 unemployed persons, making an unemployment rate of 23%. The Nauru Bureau of Statistics predicted the unemployment rate will decrease to 22% in FY2014/15.{{cite web | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=196&Itemid=279#lf-structure | title=Labour Force Projects 2014/15 | publisher=[[Nauru Bureau of Statistics]] | accessdate=3 August 2014}} The gross domestic product of Nauru was A$69.55 million in 2009, an increase of 40% increase from 2008. The GDP is broken down into three categories: primary (18.7%—agriculture, hunting, forestry, fishing, mining, and quarrying), secondary (36.5%—manufacturing, electric, gas, water, and construction), and tertiary (44.8%—trade, hotel, restaurants, and various services) industries.{{cite web | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/index.php?option=com_advlisting&view=download&fileId=52&Itemid=23 | title=Table 2.1 Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by Economic Activity in Current Prices | publisher=[[Nauru Bureau of Statistics]] | accessdate=17 July 2014}} A majority of the population are employed in phosphate mining, public administration, education, and transportation. A [[Nauru detention centre|detention centre]] was closed in 2008, which caused the unemployment rate to rise to 30%, and approximately ten percent of the population relied on working at the centre.{{Cite news | last=La Canna | first=Xavier | date=7 February 2008 | url=http://news.theage.com.au/world/nauru-hit-by-detention-centre-closure-20080207-1qs6.html | title=Nauru 'Hit' by Detention Centre Closing | newspaper=[[The Age]] | accessdate=7 July 2014}} The centre reopened in 2012{{cite web | url=http://thecommonwealth.org/our-member-countries/nauru/economy | title=Nauru: Economy | publisher=[[The Commonwealth]] | accessdate=21 July 2014}} and currently serves 1,162 prisoners, as of May 2014.{{cite web | url=http://newsroom.customs.gov.au/channels/Operation-Sovereign-Borders/releases/operational-update-23-may | title=Fact Sheet: Operational Update 23 May 2014 | publisher=[[Australian Customs and Border Protection Service]] | date=23 May 2014 | accessdate=17 July 2014}} During the 1990s, Nauru was famous for operating offshore banks, helping with [[money laundering]]. The United States State Department's International Narcotics Control Strategy Report estimated there were 400 offshore finance centres laundering an estimated $70 billion.{{Cite news | last=Seneviratne | first=Kalinga | url=http://www.atimes.com/oceania/BF29Ah01.html | title=Pressure on Pacific to Stop Money-Laundering | newspaper=[[Asia Times Online]] | date=29 June 2000 | accessdate=21 July 2014}} [[Phosphate mining in Nauru]] originally made Nauru the richest per capita nation in the world.{{Cite news | last=Squires | first=Nick | date=15 March 2008 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/7296832.stm | title=Nauru Seeks to Regain Lost Fortunes | newspaper=[[BBC News]] | accessdate=21 July 2014}} In 1968, the [[Nauru Phosphate Royalties Trust]] (NPRT) was created to invest profits from mining, so Nauru would have money after the mining was exhausted.{{Cite news | last=Seneviratne | first=Kalinga | date=26 May 1999 | url=http://www.atimes.com/oceania/AE26Ah01.html | title=Nauru Turns to Dust | newspaper=[[Asia Times Online]] | accessdate=21 July 2014}} The owners of the trust purchased a fleet of ships and aircraft, a brewery in the [[Solomon Islands]], hotels around the world, and real estate in Australia, the United States and Britain, which causes the trust to bankrupt.{{Cite news | last=Robinson | first=Natasha | date=25 October 2010 | url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/investigations/resurgence-in-sight-but-nauru-remains-a-sitting-duck/story-fn6tcs23-1225942956682 | title=Resurgence in Sight but Nauru Remains 'A Sitting Duck{{'-}} | newspaper=[[The Australian]] | accessdate=21 July 2014}} Phosphate exports peaked in 1973 with 2.3 million tonnes, but has decreased to 0.2 million tonnes in 2001.{{Harvnb|Hughes|2004|p=4}} In 2006, mining of a secondary layer of phosphate began.{{Cite web | url=http://www.mfat.govt.nz/Countries/Pacific/Nauru.php | title=Nauru | publisher=New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs | date=9 December 2013 | accessdate=11 August 2014}} == Notes == {{note|AAA|A}} {{Small|For Kiribati, the average annual income was reported as A$8,745, which was divided by 12 months to receive a monthly income.{{Cite report | ref=harv | last=Tiroa | first=Tekena | year=2006 | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/country/ki/stats/CensusSurveys/KI_Final%20HIES%20Report.pdf | title=Analytical Report on the 2006 Kiribati HIES | publisher=National Statistics Office Kiribati | accessdate=6 July 2014 | page=15}} For Australia, the minimum (A$400) and maximum (A$599) average income was taken from the 2006 census and divided by two to receive the average weekly income; this amount was multiplied by 4.33 to receive the monthly income.{{cite web | url=http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/7d12b0f6763c78caca257061001cc588/96e08af8f4178a45ca257306000d4fd4!OpenDocument | title=Census Provides an Updated Picture of the Average Australian | publisher=[[Australian Bureau of Statistics]] | date=27 June 2007 | accessdate=17 July 2014}} For Tuvalu, the 2005 monthly income was used with an inflation calculator to provide the 2006 value.{{Cite report | ref=harv | author=Tuvalu Government | year=2005 | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/country/tv/stats/Publication/Tuvalu%20HIES%20Report.pdf | title=Household Income and Expenditure Survey (HEIS) 2004/2005 | publisher=Tuvalu Government | accessdate=6 July 2014 | page=35}}}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Sources == * {{cite web|ref=harv |last=Hughes |first=Helen |year=2004 |url=http://www.cis.org.au/images/stories/issue-analysis/ia50.pdf |title=From Rags to Riches: What are Nauru's Options and how can Australia Help? |publisher=[[The Centre for Independent Studies]] |accessdate=21 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729154414/http://www.cis.org.au/images/stories/issue-analysis/ia50.pdf |archivedate=29 July 2014 |df=dmy }} * {{Cite report | ref=harv | author=Nauru Bureau of Statistics | url=https://www.spc.int/prism/country/nr/stats/Publication/Census/NR_Demog%20profile_FINAL-92-02.pdf | title=Demographic Profile of the Republic of Nauru, 1992–2002 | publisher=Nauru Bureau of Statistics | year=2002 | accessdate=2 July 2014 | volume=Part 2}} * {{Cite report | ref=harv | author=Nauru Bureau of Statistics | url=https://www.spc.int/prism/country/nr/stats/Publication/Surveys/Nauru_HIES_Rpt_final.pdf | title=Nauru Household Income and Expenditure Survey Report 2006 | publisher=Nauru Bureau of Statistics | year=2007 | accessdate=2 July 2014}} * {{Cite report | ref=harv | author=Nauru Bureau of Statistics | url=http://www.spc.int/prism/nauru/PublicDocuments/Census/Nauru_2011_Census_Report_FINAL.pdf | title=National Report on Population and Housing: Census 2011 | publisher=Nauru Bureau of Statistics | year=2011 | accessdate=27 June 2014}} {{Nauru topics}} {{Oceania topic|Demographics of}} revision.text:
The '''Dilzak''' ([[Urdu]] : '''دلزاک''') is a [[Pashtun tribe]].{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
==History== The Dilzak originally dwelled in the [[Sulaiman Mountains|Sulaiman Range]] near Eastern [[Afghanistan]] and western [[Pakistan]] border regions. They were the first of the Pashtun tribes from the region to migrate north-eastwards. They descended to the valley of [[Peshawar]] through [[Khyber Pass]] during the time of [[Samanid Dynasty]], between 750 and 850 CE.<ref>"Taarikh-e-Hazara (History of Hazara)" (Urdu-1969) by Dr. Sher Bahadur Khan Panni Page 295-313</ref>
By the time of [[Mahmud of Ghazni|Mehmood Ghaznavi]] (around 1000 CE), the Dilzak had reached the [[Indus River]] (Then called ''[[Abasin|Abaseen]]'' or ''Neelaab'').<ref>"Taareekh-e-Hazara" (Urdu) by Dr. Sher Bahadur Khan Panni_first edition_1969 p 295-313,"Taareekh-e-Wadi-e-Chhachh and Aqwaam-e-Chhachh" (Urdu) by Manzoor Awan p 175-182, , “Da Pasto Qabeelo Shajre o Mene" (Pashto) by Muhammad Umar Rond Miakhel_2001 p 346-347</ref> They participated in the campaigns of [[Mahmud of Ghazni|Mehmood Ghaznavi]] in large numbers under their leader Malik Yahya Khan.<ref>"Taareekh-e-Pashtoon" by Sher Muhammad Khan translated by Saraj Ahmed Alvi (1979) Page 200</ref> In the 500 years that followed, they extended up to [[Hassan Abdal]] and towards the North up to [[Abbotabad|Abbottabad]]. According to [[Ain-i-Akbari|Aain-i-Akbari]] (written around 1590 CE), the Dilzak were the only Pashtun tribe that possessed lands in [[Hazara, Pakistan|Hazara]] Qaarlugh at that time.<ref>''Hazara Qaarlugh'' was a term used during the Mughal period for an administrative unit collocated with the modern [[Hazara Division]] of [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Attock District]] and [[Hasan Abdal|Hassan Abdal]] (Tehsil) of [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab Province]].</ref>
Around 1520, another Pashtun tribe, the [[Yousafzai]], was expelled from [[Kabul]] by [[Mirza Ulugbeg|Mirza Ulugh Beg]] (March 22, 1394 in [[Sultaniyeh]] ([[Persia]]) – October 27, 1449 ([[Samarkand]])), a [[Timurid Empire|Timurid]] ruler and paternal uncle of the Mughal Emperor [[Babur|Zahir-ud-din Muhammad Babur]].<ref>"[[Pathans the Book|The Pathans]]" by [[Olaf Caroe|Sir Olaf Caroe]] Page 153,173/174</ref> The Yousafzai migrated to [[Peshawar]] valley where they sought and received help from the Dilzak.<ref>"Mukhtasur Taareekh-e-Pashtoon (Short History of Pashtoons) by Professor Hameedullah (2004) Page 49</ref> Later, the relationships between the two tribes deteriorated and a long war ensued.<ref>"Tawareekh-e-Hafiz Rahmat Khani" (Urdu) by Pir Moazzam Shah rearranged with notes by 'Roshan Khan', Published by Pashto Academy, Peshawar University (1976) Pages 83-570</ref>
===Return under Shahjahan=== Most of the Dilzaks returned during the reign of the Mughal Emperor [[Shah Jahan]] (January 5, 1592 – January 22, 1600), and settled in parts of [[Khyber Pakhtoonkhwa|Khyber Pakhtoonkhwa Province]] and [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab Province]] of [[Pakistan]] in their old lands.{{cn|date=October 2018}} One of them, Saleh Khan, settled with his family in [[Sarai Saleh|Sara-e-Saleh]] and Tir, both in [[Haripur District]] of [[Khyber Pakhtoonkhwa|Khyber Pakhtoonkhwa Province]] in [[Pakistan]].<ref>"Taareekh-e-Hazara" (Urdu) by Dr. Sher Bahadur Khan Panni First Edition (1969) Page 295-313</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Karlani Pashtun tribes]]

{{Infobox book | name = ''Goddesses, Whores, Wives, and Slaves: Women in Classical Antiquity'' | author = [[Sarah B. Pomeroy]] | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Women's history]], [[feminist history]], [[classical antiquity]] | published = 1975 ([[Schocken Books]])}} [[File:Pomeroy - Goddesses.jpg|thumb|Front cover of Sarah B. Pomeroy's Goddesses, Whores, Wives and Slaves. Women in Classical Antiquity (1975)]] '''''Goddesses, Whores, Wives, and Slaves: Women in Classical Antiquity''''' is a 1975 [[feminist history]] book by [[Sarah Pomeroy]]. The work covers the lives of women in [[classical antiquity|antiquity]] from the [[Greek Dark Ages]] to the death of [[Constantine the Great|Constantine]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Pomeroy|first=Sarah B.|title=Goddesses, Whores, Wives, and Slaves: Women in Classical Antiquity|year=1994|edition=2|publisher=Pimlico|location=London|page=x}}</ref> The book was one of the first English works on women's history in any period.<ref name=Foxhall-7>{{cite book|last=Foxhall|first=Lin|title=Studying Gender in Classical Antiquity|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|year=2013|page=7}}</ref> It has been used as a textbook in many university-level courses on women in classical antiquity.<ref>{{cite journal|last=McClure|first=Laura|title=Teaching a Course on Gender in the Classical World|journal=The Classical Journal|volume=92|issue=3|year=1997|page=262}}</ref>
==History== When the book was first published, reviewers commented that Pomeroy's work was an improvement on previous treatments of women in classical antiquity, such as [[John Percy Vyvian Dacre Balsdon|J. P. V. D. Balsdon's]] ''Roman Women'',<ref name=Nash-809>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Daphne|title=Review, Sarah Pomeroy, ''Goddesses, Whores, Wives, and Slaves''|year=1977|journal=Social History|volume=2|issue=6|page=809}}</ref> and it was praised for its lack of "polemical bias".<ref name=Arthur-391>{{cite journal|last=Arthur|first=Marylin B.|title=Classics|year=1976|journal=Signs|volume=2|issue=2|page=391|doi=10.1086/493365}}</ref> Marylin Arthur thought that ''Goddesses, Whores, Wives, and Slaves'' was "important",<ref name=Arthur-391/> and particularly praised the chapter on women in the [[Hellenistic period]] as "the high point of her book".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Arthur|first=Marylin B.|title=Classics|year=1976|journal=Signs|volume=2|issue=2|page=397|doi=10.1086/493365}}</ref> However, Daphne Nash criticised Pomeroy's work for its "poor level of historical argumentation" and for Pomeroy refusing to give her own opinion on disputed points.<ref name=Nash-809/> She concluded that ''Goddesses, Whores, Wives, and Slaves'' ultimately "failed to transcend the limitations of its predecessors".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Daphne|title=Review, Sarah Pomeroy, ''Goddesses, Whores, Wives, and Slaves''|year=1977|journal=Social History|volume=2|issue=6|page=810}}</ref>
==Reception== ''Goddesses, Whores, Wives, and Slaves'' is now considered to be a turning point in the study of women in ancient history. In 1994, [[Edith Hall]] said that it "marked the inauguration of women's studies within classics";<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hall|first=Edith|title=Review, Sarah Pomeroy, ''Women's History and Ancient History''|year=1994|journal=The Classical Review|volume=44|issue=2|page=367|doi=10.1017/s0009840x00289415}}</ref> in the same year, [[Shelley Haley]] wrote that it "legitimized the study of Greek and Roman women in ancient times".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Haley|first=Shelley P.|title=Classical Clichés|year=1994|journal=The Women's Review of Books|volume=12|issue=1}}</ref> Lin Foxhall, writing about the historiography of gender in classical antiquity, has described Pomeroy's book as "revolutionary", and "a major step forward" compared to existing scholarship on women in the ancient world.<ref name=Foxhall-7/>
==See also== * [[Women in ancient Rome]] * [[Women in ancient Sparta]] * [[Women in Classical Athens]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1975 books]] [[Category:20th-century history books]] [[Category:History books about ancient Greece]] [[Category:History books about ancient Rome]] [[Category:Women's history]]

The '''Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Prize''' is a program of the {{lang|de|[[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]]}} (the German Research Foundation) which awards prizes “to exceptional scientists and academics for their outstanding achievements in the field of research.”{{cite web |url= http://www.dfg.de/en/research_funding/programmes/prizes/leibniz_prize/index.html |title= Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Prize |accessdate= 2015-12-26 |publisher= [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]] }} It was established in 1985 and up to ten prizes are awarded annually to individuals or research groups working at a research institution in [[Germany]] or at a German research institution abroad.{{cite web |url= http://www.dfg.de/en/research_funding/programmes/prizes/leibniz_prize/in_brief/index.html |title= Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Prize – In Brief |accessdate= 2015-12-26 |publisher= Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft }} The prize is named after the German [[polymath]] and [[philosopher]] [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] (1646–1716) and officially called (in German) {{lang|de|Förderpreis für deutsche Wissenschaftler im Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz-Programm der Deutschen Forschungsgemeinschaft}}. It is one of the highest endowed research prizes in Germany with a maximum of €2.5 million per award. The Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft aims to improve the working conditions of outstanding scientists and academics, expand their research opportunities, relieve them of administrative tasks, and help them employ particularly qualified young researchers. Some prize winners include{{cite web |url= http://www.dfg.de/download/pdf/gefoerderte_projekte/preistraeger/gwl-preis/leibniz_preistraeger_86_17.pdf |title=Liste der Leibniz-Preisträger 1986 – 2017|trans-title=List of all prize recipients 1986-2015 |date= 2017 |accessdate= 2017-03-15 |publisher= [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]] | language=German}} [[Stefan Hell]] (2008), [[Gerd Faltings]] (1996), [[Peter Gruss]] (1994), [[Svante Pääbo]] (1992), [[Theodor W. Hänsch]] (1989), [[Erwin Neher]] (1987), [[Bert Sakmann]] (1987), [[Jürgen Habermas]] (1986), [[Hartmut Michel]] (1986), and [[Christiane Nüsslein-Volhard]] (1986). ==Prizewinners== Source: Homepage of Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft{{cite web |url = http://www.dfg.de/en/funded_projects/prizewinners/leibniz_prize/index.html |title = Prizewinners and award ceremonies |publisher= [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]] |date = 2015 |accessdate= 2 January 2016 }} === 2018-2010 ===
[[#2018|2018]] | [[#2017|2017]] | [[#2016|2016]] | [[#2015|2015]] | [[#2014|2014]] | [[#2013|2013]] | [[#2012|2012]] | [[#2011|2011]] | [[#2010|2010]]

DFG Honours Ten Researchers |publisher= [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]] |date = 10 December 2015 |accessdate= 3 January 2016 }} * [[Frank Bradke]], Neuroregeneration, [[German Center for [[University of Bonn]] * [[Christian Hertweck]], Biological Chemistry, [[Leibniz Institute for Natural Product Research]] and Infection Biology – Hans Knöll Institute (HKI), Jena, and [[University of Jena]] * [[Friedrich Lenger]], Modern and Contemporary History, [[University of Giessen]] * [[Hartmut Leppin]], Ancient History, [[Goethe University Frankfurt am Main]] * [[Steffen Martus]], Modern German Literature, [[Humboldt University of Berlin]] * {{ill|Tobias Moser|de}}, Auditory Sensing/Otolaryngology, [[University of Göttingen]] '''2014:''' {{anchor|2014}} * [[Artemis Alexiadou]], Linguistics, [[University of Stuttgart]] * [[Armin von Bogdandy]], Foreign public law and international law, [[Max Planck Institute for Comparative Public Law and International Law]], Heidelberg * [[Andreas Dreizler]], Combustion research, [[Technische Universität Darmstadt]] * [[Christof Schulz]], Combustion and gas dynamics, [[Universität Duisburg-Essen]] * [[Nicole Dubilier]], Marine ecology, [[Max Planck Institute for Marine Microbiology]], Bremen, and [[Universität Bremen]] * [[Leif Kobbelt]], Informatics and computer graphics, [[RWTH Aachen]] * [[Laurens Molenkamp]], Experimental solid-state physics, [[Universität Würzburg]] * [[Brigitte Röder]], Biological psychology/neuro-psychology, [[Universität Hamburg]] * [[Irmgard Sinning]], Structural biology, [[Universität Heidelberg]] * [[Rainer Waser]], Nanoelectronics/Materials science, [[RWTH Aachen]] and [[Peter Grünberg Institute]], Research Center Jülich * [[Lars Zender]], Hepatology/oncology,
