{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Spaniards in Mexico
''Españoles en México'' |image = Acercamiento de la Fuente de Cibeles México.jpg |caption = Fuente de Cibeles, Mexico City. |population = '''123,189''' Spanish nationals (2016){{cite web|title=Estadística del Padrón de Españoles Residentes en el Extranjero a 1 de enero de 2016|url=http://www.ine.es/prensa/np962.pdf|publisher=Instituto Nacional de Estadística|accessdate=18 March 2016}}{{Ref |population |Note}} |langs = {{hlist|[[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''([[Peninsular Spanish]] dialects, and [[Mexican Spanish]] dialects)''
Minority speaks [[Galician language|Galician]] | [[Catalan language|Catalan]] | [[Basque language|Basque]]}} |rels = Predominantly [[Roman Catholicism]],
also [[Sephardic Judaism]] |related = [[Mestizos in Mexico|Mestizo Mexican]], other [[Spanish diaspora]] |footnotes = {{note |population}}Note: 19,223 individuals were born in Spain, 100,067 in Mexico, 3,689 in other countries and 210 were n/a. }} {{Spanish people}} '''Spanish Mexicans''' are citizens or residents of [[Mexico]] who identify as [[Spaniards|Spanish]] as a result of nationality or ancestry.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} Spanish immigration to Mexico began in the early 1500s and spans to the present day.{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/379167/Mexico/27384/Ethnic-groups|title=Mexico - History, Geography, Facts, & Points of Interest|website=Britannica.com|accessdate=2017-08-28}} There are three recognized large-scale Spanish immigration waves to Mexico: the first arrived during the colonial period, the second during the ''Porfiriato'', the third after the Spanish Civil War and the fourth (and current) after the 2008 financial crisis. The first Spanish settlement was established in February 1519, as a result of the landing of [[Hernán Cortés]] in the [[Yucatan Peninsula]], accompanied by about 11 ships, 500 men, 13 horses and a small number of cannons.Bernard Grunberg, ''"La folle aventure d'Hernán Cortés''", in ''[[L'Histoire]]'' n°322, July–August 2007 In March 1519, Cortés formally claimed the land for the [[Habsburg Spain|Spanish crown]], and the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|conquest of the Aztec Empire]], a key event in the Spanish conquest of modern-day Mexico in general, was completed in 1521. ==Arrival of the Spanish== {{Main|Spanish conquest of Mexico}} [[File:Rafael Ximeno y Planes - Portrait of Manuel Tolsá - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|220px|left|[[Manuel Tolsá]], prominent architect in the Viceroyalty of New Spain.]] The social composition of this immigration of the late sixteenth century included both common people, illiterates, and aristocrats with titles of counts and marquises, all of which quickly disintegrated over the [[Mexican territory|territory]]. The discovery of new deposits of various minerals in the central and northern areas (from Sonora to the southern provinces of Mexico) allowed New Spain to gradually occupy a privileged position, especially in the extraction of silver. Mining allowed the development of associated activities such as manufacturing and agriculture, that turned the Bajío regions or the valleys of Mexico and Puebla into prosperous agricultural regions with incipient industrial activity. In the 16th century, following the military conquest of most of the new continents, perhaps 240,000 Spaniards entered ports in the Americas. They were joined by 450,000 in the next century.{{Cite journal|url= http://www.millersville.edu/~columbus/data/art/AXTELL01.ART |title= The Columbian Mosaic in Colonial America |first= James |last= Axtell |journal= Humanities |date= September–October 1991 |volume= 12 |issue= 5 |pages= 12–18 |accessdate= 2008-10-08 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080517052031/http://www.millersville.edu/~columbus/data/art/AXTELL01.ART |archivedate = May 17, 2008}} Since the conquest of [[Mexico]], this region became the principal destination of Spanish colonial settlers in the 16th century. The first Spaniards who arrived in Mexico were soldiers and sailors from [[Extremadura]], [[Andalucía]] and [[La Mancha]] after the [[conquest of the Americas]].{{cite web|url=http://www.emperadores.es/circuitos/tierra-de-conquistadores|title=Emperadores|website=Emperadores.es|accessdate=2017-08-28}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allspainaccommodation.com/extremadura/extremadura.htm|title=Extremadura, Spain - Accommodation and Travel Guide - Hotels & Paradores - Rural Tourism|first=|last=Anne|website=Allspainaccommodation.com|accessdate=2017-08-28}} At the end of the 16th century both commoner and aristocrat from Spain were migrating to Mexico. Also, a few Canarian families emigrated to Mexico in the 17th century (as in the case of the Azuaje families) and when the Spanish crown encouraged Canarian emigration to the Americas through the ''Tributo de sangre'' (Blood Tribute) in the 18th century, many of them settled in Yucatán, where by the 18th century they controlled the trade network that distributed goods throughout the peninsula; their descendants are still counted among the most influential families of direct Spanish descent in Mexico. During the 20th century, another group of Canarians settled in Mexico in the early 1930s, and as with Galician and other Spanish immigrants of the time, there were high rates of illiteracy and impoverishment among them, but they adapted relatively quickly. ==History== After of the independence of Mexico, a racism emerged against Spanish people in this new nation; in August 1827 to 1834, by the decree issued during the government of Lorenzo de Zavala, that expelled many Spaniards from the [[State of Mexico]] and killed Spanish families. The state government, influenced by English masons or Yorkers, based on the [[Plan of Iguala]] and [[Treaty of Córdoba]], stripped Spaniards of their haciendas, farms, ranches and properties in this state, leading many widows and orphans to flee to other Mexican states.Estado de México, Textos de su historia, Institute Mora, Mexico State government, Toluca, 1996. pp. 227-230.[http://www.redalyc.org/pdf/600/60056205.pdf Los españoles en el México Independiente] Colegio de México, pp. 624-627 On December 20, 1827, was repealed the law Spanish expulsion by state deputies, many Creole families who were in misery, some returned to their farms and ranches protected by state congress deputies.Estado de México, Textos de su historia, Institute Mora, Mexico State government, Toluca, 1996. pp.230. In the constitution of 1857, the ambiguities about Mexican citizens are removed, the Spaniards were recognized foreign people, they no longer recovered the important position during the colonial period.[http://www.redalyc.org/pdf/600/60056205.pdf Los españoles en el México Independiente] Colegio de México, pp. 620-622 [[File:StatueSpanishexMalecon.JPG|thumb|150px|left|Monument dedicated to the refugees of the [[Spanish Civil]] War in [[Veracruz, Veracruz]].]] [[File:Los niños de Morelia. Niños españoles que encontraron en México un hogar.JPG|220px|thumbnail|Numerous Spanish children were sent to Mexico by their families to escape the [[Spanish Civil War]]. President [[Lázaro Cárdenas]] is pictured with a group in the bottom-left.]] [[File:El exilio español en la CD de México (23).JPG|thumb|220px|right|La Unió Catalanista de Mèxic, in 1953.]] In the period 1850-1950, 3.5 million Spanish left for the Americas, and Mexico became one of the chief destinations, in 1876 Mexico establishes relationships with Spain; a second wave was particularly in the Northern region where president [[Porfirio Diaz]] started a campaign of European immigration to supply labor.{{cite web |author=Patricia Rivas |url=http://www.radiomundial.com.ve/yvke/noticia.php?16783 |title=Reconocerán nacionalidad española a descendientes de exiliados :: YVKE Mundial |publisher=Radiomundial.com.ve |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110105210817/http://www.radiomundial.com.ve/yvke/noticia.php?16783 |archivedate=2011-01-05 |df= }} In 1910, there were 30,000 Spaniards in Mexico, they participated in economic activities as agricultural labors and trade in urban areas, they could not influence the country's political life. Most recent migrants came during the [[Spanish Civil War]]. More than 25,000 Spanish refugees settled in Mexico between 1939 and 1942, largely during the administration of President Lazaro Cardenas del Río. Some of the migrants returned to Spain after the civil war, but many more remained in Mexico.{{cite web|url=http://www.milenio.com/firmas/carlos_tello_diaz/Exilio-espanol-Mexico_18_400339968.html|title=Exilio español en México|first=Carlos Tello|last=Díaz|website=Milenio.com|accessdate=2017-08-28}} The ''Children of Morelia'' was formed in 1937 by 456 Spanish children, Republican's sons, which were brought from Spain in the vapor ship with French flag named Mexique, at the request of the Mexican Assistance Committee by Pueblo Spanish, based in Barcelona city. This children were received by Mexican President Lázaro Cardenas del Río. Of these refugees is named as soon as "intellectual immigration" or "elite" was made up of approximately 25% of the total. It also notes that also came in greater numbers "factory workers and peasants" as well as soldiers, sailors and pilots, statesmen, economists, and businessmen, all linked to the Republican government defeated in war.{{cite web|url=http://www.red-redial.net/doc_adj/4934-exilio-espanol.pdf|format=PDF|title=Exilio Espanol Exhibition|website=Red-redial.et|accessdate=2017-08-28}} Due to the [[2008 Financial Crisis]] and the resulting economic decline and high unemployment in Spain, many Spaniards have been emigrating to Mexico to seek new opportunities.{{cite web|url=http://newamericamedia.org/2013/02/as-spains-economy-worsens-young-adults-flock-to-mexico-for-jobs.php|title=As Spain's Economy Worsens, Young Adults Flock to Mexico for Jobs - New America Media|website=Newamericamedia.org|accessdate=2017-08-28}} For example, during the last quarter of 2012, a number of 7,630 work permits were granted to Spaniards.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nathanielparishflannery/2013/04/30/as-spain-falters-spaniards-look-to-latin-america/|title=As Spain Falters, Spaniards Look to Latin America|first=Nathaniel Parish|last=Flannery|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=2017-08-28}} ==Economic and social issues== The actual Spanish community in Mexico is integrated principally by business men, business women, actors, actresses, academics, artists and professional students, Mexico is now an important country by inversions in Latin America,[http://www.milenio.com/negocios/FTMercados-Gas_Natural_Fenos-inversionistas_en_Mexico_0_441556195.html Grupo Milenio] España el mayor inversor de México, January 17, 2017. when last time was poor people named ''gachupines'' or ''refugiados'' (war refugees). Now many Spaniards are owners of restaurants, department stores, supermarkets, bank institutions, luxury hotels, motels, gourmet bakeries, stationeries, ultramarine stores, trip agencies, building companies, textile factories, gas stations, iron factories, fashion houses, architecture studios, engineer offices, transport services, also private schools and universities, and cultural institutes as Intituto Cervantes, Casa de España or Ateneo Español. ==Discrimination and stereotypes== {{Main|Hispanophobia}} [[File:El exilio español en la CD de México (13).JPG|thumb|230px|left|Cartoon with Spanish people in [[Mexico City]].]] The word ''gachupín'' is used for Spaniards who live in Mexico and Guatemala{{cite web|url=http://es.thefreedictionary.com/gachup%C3%ADn|title=gachupín|website=Es.thefreedictionary.com|accessdate=28 August 2017}} as a slur, referring to conquistadors and people from Spain.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.lavozdegalicia.es/lamiradaenlalengua/2013/01/26/los-nuevos-gachupines/|title=Los nuevos gachupines - La mirada en la lengua|website=Blogs.lavozdegalicia.es|accessdate=28 August 2017}} Official history says [[Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla]] mentioned in the Grito de Dolores; ''Mueran los gachupines'', (Death to the gachupines!).{{cite web|url=http://www.zocalo.com.mx/seccion/articulo/el-grito-de-hidalgo-fue-contra-los-gachupines|title=El Grito de Hidalgo fue contra ‘los gachupines’ [Independencia - 15/09/2012 - Periódico Zócalo|website=Zocalo.com.mx|accessdate=28 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://capsuladelengua.wordpress.com/2009/07/14/gachupines/|title=Gachupines|date=14 July 2009|website=Capsuladelengua.wordpress.com|accessdate=28 August 2017}} [[Diego Rivera]] was a Mexican painter, who caused controversy with a mural named ''La leyenda negra de la Conquista'' (The black legend of Conquest), painted between 1929 and 1930, he was accused of Hispanophobia creating diplomatic conflicts between Mexican government with Spanish government.[http://www.redalyc.org/pdf/3251/325146749010.pdf La utopia de forjar una sola raza para la nación], González Salinas, Omar Fabián, Historia Y MEMORIA magazine, 2016, number 13, p. 320, Tunja, Colombia. The stereotypes about Spaniards in Mexico are men with barb and boina, people smoking ''habanos'' and drinking wine, many newspaper's cartoons describes this images for gachupines or Spanish people.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} == Education == [[File:Colmex007.JPG|thumb|right|220px|The [[El Colegio de México|Colegio de México]].]] Important Spanish schools remain in Mexico, such as Colegio Madrid of Mexico City, a scholarly institute founded in 1941 by Spanish immigrants and Mexican teachers. This is a private school for elementary education.{{cite web|url=http://www.colegiomadrid.edu.mx/index.php/historia|title=Colegio Madrid, A.C. - Historia|website=Colegiomadrid.edu.mx|accessdate=2017-08-28}} The [[El Colegio de México|Colegio de México]] (Colmex) was an organization of Spanish civil war exiles called firstly "Casa de España en México" (House of Spain in Mexico). In 1939, Alfonso Reyes would be president of the "Colegio" until his death. Historian [[Daniel Cosío Villegas]] played an important role in its institutionalization and the Colegio's library bears his name. ==Spanish culture in Mexico== [[File:El exilio español en la CD de México (20).JPG|thumb|right|220px|''Jocs florals de la llengua catalana'' was a Catalan publication, printed in [[Mexico City]].]] [[File:Charros en Tequixquiac (2).JPG|thumb|right|220px|[[Charrería]] is a Mexican sport with Spanish origins ([[Santiago Tequixquiac]] fair).]] [[File:San marcos bullfight 01.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Bullfighting in San Marcos festival of [[Aguascalientes City]].]] [[File:Procesion del Silencio SLP115.JPG|thumb|right|220px|[[Holy Week procession]] of [[San Luis Potosí City]].]] [[File:Estudiantina Guanajuato.jpg|thumb|right|220px|The [[Tuna (music)|estudiantina]] in Cervantino festival of [[Guanajuato City]].]] === Languages === {{Main|Spanish language|Mexican Spanish}} [[Spanish language|Spanish]] was brought to [[Mexico]] around 500 years ago. As a result of Mexico City's central role in the colonial administration of [[Viceroyalty of New Spain|New Spain]], the population of the city included relatively large numbers of speakers from [[Spain]]. Mexico City ([[Tenochtitlán]]) had also been the capital of the [[Aztec]] Empire, and many speakers of the Aztec language [[Nahuatl]] continued to live there and in the surrounding region, outnumbering the Spanish-speakers for several generations. Consequently, Mexico City tended historically to exercise a standardizing effect over the entire country, more or less, evolving into a distinctive dialect of [[Spanish language|Spanish]] which incorporated a significant number of [[Hispanicization|Hispanicized]] Nahuatl words. During the Spanish Exile, the [[Catalan language]] was expressed by writers and poets in Mexico, the Orfeó Català de Mèxic was a mecca for Catalan speakers and artists.{{cite web|url=http://crai.ub.edu/ca/coneix-el-crai/biblioteques/biblioteca-pavello-republica/jocs-florals|title=Els Jocs Florals de la Llengua Catalana a l'exili (1941-1977) - CRAI UB|website=Crai.ub.edu|accessdate=28 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ocm.cat/index.php/es/orfeo-mx/historia-mx|title=Historia|first=Super|last=User|website=Ocm.cat|accessdate=28 August 2017}} === Charreria === Charreria, a word encompassing all aspects of the art, evolved from the traditions that came to Mexico from [[Salamanca, Spain]] in the 16th century. When the Spanish first settled in [[Colonial Mexico]], they were under orders to raise horses named ''criollos'' (Spanish Creole people), but not to allow the [[Indigenous peoples of Mexico|indigenous people]] to ride. However, by 1528 the Spanish had very large [[Hacienda|cattle-raising estates]] and found it necessary to employ indigenous people as [[vaquero]]s or Criole herdsman, who soon became excellent horsemen. Smaller landholders, known as rancheros or ranchers, were the first genuine [[charro]]s and they are credited as the inventors of the charreada.{{cite web |url=http://dnn.epcc.edu/nwlibrary/borderlands/10_la_charreada.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816195630/http://dnn.epcc.edu/nwlibrary/borderlands/10_la_charreada.htm |archivedate=2011-08-16 |df= }} === Bullfighting === [[Bullfighting]] arrived in Mexico with the first Spaniards and the rest of Latin America in the 16th century. Records are found of the first bullfights debuted in Mexico on June 26, 1526, with a bullfight in [[Mexico City]] held in honor of explorer [[Hernán Cortés]], who had just come back from [[Honduras]] (then known as Las Hibueras). From that point on, bullfights were staged all over Mexico as part of various civic, social and religious celebrations. Today, there are about 220 permanent bullrings throughout Mexico with the largest venue of its kind is the [[Plaza de toros México]] in central [[Mexico City]] which opened in 1946 and seats 48,000 people.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/mexico/central_mexico.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-05-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605140518/http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/mexico/central_mexico.shtml |archivedate=2011-06-05 |df= }} === Holy week === Holy week is a Spanish tradition represented in many Mexican cities as San Luis Potosí City, Taxco de Alarcón or Morelia, this religious representation is very similar to Sevilla Holy week procession o ''Semana Mayor'' from other Spanish cities.{{Citation needed|date=October 2016}}. === Spanish place names in Mexico === There are hundreds of places in Mexico named after places in [[Spain]] or have Spanish names due to the [[Spanish colonialism]], [[Spanish people|Spanish]] settlers and [[explorer]]s. These include: *[[Guadalajara, Jalisco]], after [[Guadalajara, Spain]], *[[Mérida, Yucatán]] after [[Mérida, Spain]] *[[Zamora, Michoacán]] after [[Zamora, Spain]] *[[León, Guanajuato]] after [[León, Spain]] *[[Valladolid, Yucatán]] after [[Valladolid, Spain]] and [[Morelia, Michoacán]] formerly named Valladolid de Michoacán *[[Nuevo León]] named after the former [[Kingdom of León]] in Spain *[[Monterrey, Mexico|Monterrey]] city was named after the Countess of Monterrei (a city in [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], Spain), wife of the Viceroy of [[New Spain]] [[Gaspar de Zúñiga, 5th Count of Monterrey]], Count of [[Monterrey, Spain]]. *[[Salamanca, Guanajuato]] named after [[Salamanca]], Spain *[[Burgos, Tamaulipas]] named after [[Burgos]], Spain *[[Linares, Nuevo León]] named after [[Linares, Jaén|Linares]], Spain *[[Durango, Durango]] named after [[Durango, Spain]] *[[Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas]] after [[Laredo, Cantabria]], [[Spain]] *[[Córdoba, Veracruz]] after [[Córdoba, Spain]] *[[:es: Zaragoza (Veracruz)|Zaragoza, Veracruz]] after [[Zaragoza, Spain]] *[[:es: Zaragoza (Puebla)|Zaragoza, Puebla]] after [[Zaragoza, Spain]] *[[Medellín, Veracruz]] after [[Medellín, Spain]] *[[Puebla de Zaragoza]] after [[Puebla de Sanabria]] *[[Compostela, Nayarit]] after [[Santiago de Compostela]] *[[Villahermosa, Tabasco]] after [[Villahermosa del Campo]], Spain *[[Reynosa, Tamaulipas]] after [[Reinosa]], Cantabria, Spain *[[Madrid, Colima]] after [[Madrid]], Spain *[[Matamoros, Tamaulipas]] after [[Valle de Matamoros]], Extremadura, Spain *[[Altamira, Tamaulipas]] after [[Basurto-Zorroza|Altamira]], Bilbao, Spain *[[Arandas, Jalisco]] after [[Aranda de Duero|Aranda]], Aragón, Spain *[[Arandas, Guanajuato]] after [[Aranda de Duero|Aranda]], Aragón, Spain *[[Guadalcázar, San Luis Potosí]] after [[Guadalcázar (Córdoba)|Guadalcázar]], Córdoba, Spain *[[Lerma, State of Mexico]] after [[Lerma, Province of Burgos|Lerma]], Castile and León, Spain *[[Lerma, Campeche]] after [[Lerma, Province of Burgos|Lerma]], Castile and León, Spain *[[Candelaria, Campeche]] after [[Candelaria, Tenerife|Candelaria]], Tenerife Canary Islands, Spain *[[Granada, Yucatán]] after [[Granada]], Andalusia, Spain == Principal areas of settlement == {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = [[Guadalajara, Jalisco]], [[Mexico]] founded by [[Nuño Beltrán de Guzmán]], is named after [[Guadalajara, Spain]]. | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Plaza de Armas y Catedral.jpg | width1 = 200 | caption1 = | alt1 = Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico | image2 = Torreón de Álvarez Fáñez2.jpg | width2 = 200 | caption2 = | alt2 =Guadalajara, Spain }} The Asturians are a very large community that has a long history in Mexico, dating from colonial times to the present. [http://www.economia.unam.mx/cladhe/registro/ponencias/214_abstract.pdf Economía UNAM] Los asturianos y la modernización commercial de México y España en el siglo XX, 2005. There are about 42,000 people of Asturian birth in Mexico{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}. The Catalans are also very numerous in Mexico. According to sources from the Catalan community, there are approximately 12,000 Catalan-born around the country.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}. There are also as many as 8,500 [[Basques]]{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}, 6,000 Galicians{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}, and 1,600 Canary Islanders{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}. The largest population of Spanish descent are located in Mexico Valley, Puebla-Veracruz region, Bajío region, Guadalajara Valley, Altos de Jalisco, Northern region and Riviera Maya, where they make up the largest proportion of the Spanish population. Large populations are found in the states like [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico State]], [[Veracruz]], [[Puebla]], [[Jalisco]], [[Nuevo León]], [[Aguascalientes]], [[Durango]], [[Guanajuato]], [[Querétaro]], and [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]]. {{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} Also, Northern Mexico is inhabited by many millions of Spanish descendants. {{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} Some states like [[Zacatecas]], [[Sinaloa]], [[Baja California]], [[Sonora]], [[San Luis Potosí]] and [[Tamaulipas]]. As the [[Spanish Empire|Spanish royal]] Government doted the [[New Spain]] from Kingdoms and Territories, a great part of them followed names. So we can find lots of Basque criollos in [[Durango]] and Southern [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]] as those territories were part of the [[Nueva Vizcaya, New Spain|Kingdom of New Vizcay]], Galician descendants in [[Jalisco]] being part of the [[Nueva Galicia|Kingdom of New Galicia]]. === Mexico City === [[File:Centro Gallego de México (1).JPG|thumb|left|220px|Centro Gallego de México in Mexico City.]] [[File:Casa Universitaria del Libro (4).JPG|thumb|right|220px|Old Centro Asturiano de México in Mexico City.]] [[File:Ciudad de Puebla (Centro gallego de México).jpg|thumb|left|220px|Centro Gallego de México in Sebastián de Aparicio Romería, Puebla City.]] [[File:04242012semana de la cultura779.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Flamenco dance in ITESM Mexico City.]] Mexico City has the biggest Spanish population in the country, in this city are all the Spanish institutions as Embassy of Spain, cultural centers as soon as Centro Asturiano, Centro Gallego, Casa de Madrid, Casa de Andalucía, Centro Montañes, Orfeo Catalán de Mexico, Centro Vasco, Centro Canario, Centro Republicano Español, Ateneo Español, Casino Español, Asociación Valenciana, Centro Castellano, and health institutions as the Beneficiencia Española, Hospital Español and Hospital-ito.[http://www.guiadelcentrohistorico.mx/kmcero/oficios-y-beneficios/un-pedazo-de-espa-en-m-xico Un pedazo de España en México] Centro histórico, January 17, 2017. Also in Mexico City stay important Spanish schools and universities as Colegio Madrid, Universidad Iberoamericana, Colegio de México and Universidad Anahuac. === Puebla City === Puebla City is the other biggest Spanish population in Mexico, here is ''Parque España'', an interesting social community and school from Spaniards and Spanish Mexicans descendants. The Centro Gallego de México makes a Beato Sebastián de Aparicio romería to Puebla City each year, this event is an interesting Galician community with Folk music and Galician dances outside the Old San Francisco convento to Downtown Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla State. === Veracruz City === Veracruz City is the first biggest Spanish population in Mexico, interesting social community, and schools, universities, health institutes from Spaniards and Spanish Mexicans descendants. All times always, in Veracruz City there are Spanish communities in the commerce, factory, nave shipping companies, and education. === Numbers === Spanish descendants make up the largest group of Europeans in Mexico and a majority of Mexicans have some degree of Spanish descent. Most of their ancestors arrived during the colonial period but further hundreds of thousands have since then immigrated, especially during the [[Spanish Civil War]] in the 1930s.{{cite web|url=http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=083e0b4728d31cd23a57533cf02c46c5|title=New America Media|website=News.newamericamedia.org|accessdate=2017-08-28}} According to CIA World Factbook, whites make up 10% of Mexico's population.CIA World Factbook. See also [[White Latin American]] for external sources. The Encyclopædia Britannica states those of predominantly European descent make up closer to one-sixth (≈17%) of the Mexican population.{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/379167/Mexico/27384/Ethnic-groups?anchor=ref394520|title=Mexico - History, Geography, Facts, & Points of Interest|website=Britannica.com|accessdate=2017-08-28}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5 | Spaniards in Mexico |- ! Year ! Residents |- | 2010 | 77,069 (INE){{cite web|url=http://www.ine.es/prensa/np594.pdf|title=Inmigrantes españoles INE 2010.|website=Ine.es|accessdate=2017-08-28}} |- | 2011 | 86,658 (INE){{cite web|url=http://www.ine.es/prensa/np649.pdf|title=Inmigrantes españoles INE 2011.|website=Ine.es|accessdate=2017-08-28}} |- | 2012 | 94.617 (INE){{cite web|url=http://www.ine.es/prensa/np705.pdf|title=Inmigrantes españoles INE 2012.|website=Ine.es|accessdate=2017-08-28}} |- | 2013 | 100.782 (INE){{cite web|url=http://www.ine.es/prensa/np773.pdf|title=Inmigrantes españoles INE 2013.|website=Ine.es|accessdate=2017-08-28}} |- | 2014 | 108,314 (INE){{cite web|url=http://www.ine.es/prensa/np898.pdf|title=Inmigrantes españoles INE 2014.|website=Ine.es|accessdate=2017-08-28}} |- | 2015 | 115,620 (INE){{cite web|url=http://www.ine.es/prensa/np898.pdf|title=Inmigrantes españoles INE 2015.|website=Ine.es|accessdate=2017-08-28}} |- | 2016 | 123,189 (INE){{cite web|url=http://www.ine.es/prensa/np962.pdf|title=Inmigrantes españoles INE 2016.|website=Ine.es|accessdate=2017-08-28}} |} ==Notable Spanish Mexicans== File:Luis Buñuel.JPG|[[Luis Buñuel]], director and film producer. File:MOURIÑO1.JPG|[[Juan Camilo Mouriño]], politician. File:Belinda Peregrin Schull.jpg|[[Belinda Peregrín]], singer an actress. ==See also== *[[Basque Mexicans]] *[[Mexico–Spain relations]] *[[Immigration to Mexico]] *[[Mexicans of European descent]] *[[Hispanos of New Mexico]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://fusion.net/story/5158/how-the-spanish-civil-war-drove-my-family-to-mexico/ How the Spanish Civil War Drove My Family to Mexico] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cjSa3uvVUQc Los que llegaron, Españoles] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eckJbIMjFHs Los niños de Morelia] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AwzhN_CHJLQ Romería del Pilar in Parque España, Puebla City.] {{Ethnic groups in Mexico}} {{Spanish diaspora}} [[Category:Mexican people of Spanish descent| ]] [[Category:European Mexican]] [[Category:Spanish diaspora in North America]] [[Category:Spanish diaspora by country]] [[Category:Mexico–Spain relations]] [[Category:Immigration to Mexico]] [[Category:Spanish Mexican]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mexico]]

page.title: The End of the Red Line

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''The End of the Red Line''}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Endoftheredline - from Commons.JPG | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 250px | title = The End of the Red Line | alt = 800 slender twelve foot long red neon rods are suspended from wires attached to the ceiling above the subway tracks. | artist = [[Alejandro Sina]]
[[Moira Sina]] | year = {{Start date|1985}} | height_metric = | width_metric = | height_imperial = 320 | width_imperial = 10 | imperial_unit = ft | metric_unit = m | city = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Massachusetts]] | museum = [[Alewife (MBTA station)|Alewife station]] | coordinates={{coord|42.39564|-71.14092|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline, title}} | owner = [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority]] }} '''''The End of the Red Line''''' is an abstract [[light sculpture]] by [[Alejandro Sina|Alejandro]] and [[Moira Sina]]. It is located at [[Alewife (MBTA station)]], in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. Approximately 800 red [[Neon art|neon tubes]] are suspended from a {{convert|320|ft|m|adj=on}} long section of the station ceiling, directly above the outbound train tracks. The intensity of the light is varied gradually over time.{{cite web|url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!294610~!0#focus |title=The End of the Red Line, (sculpture) |publisher=Smithsonian American Art Museum |work=Siris-artinventories.si.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-09-16}} ==See also== *[[Arts on the Line]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite web|title=Arts On The Line Alewife Station|url=http://www2.cambridgema.gov/cac/public_art_tour/map_01_alwife.html|work=2002|publisher=Cambridge Arts Council|accessdate=14 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120806144833/http://www2.cambridgema.gov/cac/public_art_tour/map_01_alwife.html|archivedate=6 August 2012|df=}} {{DEFAULTSORT:End of the Red Line}} [[Category:Public art]] [[Category:Cambridge, Massachusetts]] [[Category:1985 works]] [[Category:Neon lighting]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = Turkish Canadians
''Türk asıllı Kanadalılar'' | image = [[File:Turkish Canadians 2005.jpg|280px]] | caption = Turkish Canadians at the [[Victoria Day]] Parade in 2005 | population = 63,955 (by ancestry, [[Canada 2016 Census|2016 Census]]){{cite web |url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2016/dp-pd/hlt-fst/imm/Table.cfm?Lang=E&T=31&Geo=01&SO=4D |title=Ethnic Origin, both sexes, age (total), Canada, 2016 Census – 25% Sample data | series= [[Canada 2016 Census]] |publisher=[[Statistics Canada]] |accessdate=6 November 2017}} | popplace = {{Flatlist| * [[Toronto]] * [[Montreal]] * [[Vancouver]] * [[London, Ontario|London]] * [[Ottawa]] * [[Calgary]] * [[Edmonton]] }} | langs = {{Flatlist| * [[Turkish language|Turkish]] * [[Canadian English]] * [[Canadian French]] }} | rels = Predominantly [[Sunni Islam]], significant minority of [[Shi'a Islam]] ([[Alevi]]), [[ Christianity]] as well as [[ Judaism]] }} '''Turkish Canadians''' ({{lang-tr|Türk asıllı Kanadalılar;}} literally "Turkish-originating Canadians") are [[Canadians|Canadian citizens]] of [[Turkish people|Turkish]] descent, or [[Turkey]]-born people who reside in [[Canada]].{{Harvnb|Karpat|2004|loc=632}}{{Harvnb|Powell|2005|loc=297}} According to the [[Canada 2016 Census|2016 Census]] there were 63,955 Canadians who claimed full or partial Turkish descent. == History == [[Turkish people|Turks]] first began to immigrate to [[Canada]] in small numbers from the [[Ottoman Empire]]. However, significant migration initially began in the late 1950s and early 1960s when the Turkish government encouraged student education abroad.{{Harvnb|Aksan|1999|loc=1277}}. There have also been Turks fleeing from unrest and oppression in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Cyprus]] who arrived in Canada as both [[political]] and [[economic]] [[refugees]]. ===Ottoman migration=== In 1901, Canada had between 300–400 [[Muslim]] residents, equally divided between Turks and Syrian Arabs.{{Harvnb|Abu-Laban|1983|loc=76}}. By 1911, the size of the Muslim community had increased to about 1,500, of whom 1,000 were of Turkish origin and the remainder were Arabs. During the pre-[[World War I]] period Turks were to be found in [[mining]] and [[logging]] camps across Canada. However, due to bad relations between the [[Ottoman Empire]] and [[Europe]], further migration was made difficult for the Turks and the Canadian government discouraged "[[Asian people|Asian]]" immigration. Thus, by the onset of World War I, Canada witnessed the return of many Turkish immigrants who were then classified as "enemy aliens". Another reason for the return-migration of Ottoman Turks was because for the majority of Turks, the founding of the new republic of Turkey in 1923 was a greater incentive to stay at home.{{Harvnb|Aksan|1999|loc=1276}}. ===Mainland Turkish migration=== In the late 1950s and early 1960s, the government of [[Turkey]] encouraged and financially supported Turkish students to study in Canada. Thus, the early 1960s consisted primarily of students and professionals, especially doctors and engineers.{{Harvnb|Powell|2005|loc=298}} Significant Turkish immigration began during the 1960s and 1970s; most Turks went to Canada for educational and economic opportunities. According to the 1972 Canada census there were 9,342 Turkish-born persons living in Canada. ===Bulgarian Turks migration=== In 1989, [[Turks in Bulgaria]] were fleeing from the unrest and oppression of the Bulgarian government; many have arrived in Canada as political and economic refugees. ===Turkish Cypriot migration=== During the 1950s, [[Turkish Cypriots]] started to leave [[Cyprus]] for political reasons when the [[Greek Cypriots]] held a referendum in which 95.7% of Greek Cypriots supported [[enosis]], the union of Cyprus with [[Greece]]. By 1963, inter-ethnic fighting broke out in [[Cyprus]], with [[Turkish Cypriots]] bearing the heavier cost in terms of casualties and some 25,000 Turkish Cypriots became internally displaced accounting to about a fifth of their population.{{Harvnb|Cassia|2007|loc=19}}. Tension continued to grow by the late 1960s and approximately 60,000 Turkish Cypriots left their homes and moved into enclaves.{{Harvnb|Tocci|2004|loc=53}}. This resulted in an [[Emigration|exodus]] of more Turkish Cypriots from the island, many migrating to [[Canada]]. In 1983, Turkish Cypriots [[Declaration of Independence of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus|unilaterally proclaimed]] the establishment of their own state, the [[Northern Cyprus|Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus]] (TRNC), which has since remained internationally unrecognized except by Turkey. Since the division of the island, the [[Economy of Northern Cyprus|Turkish Cypriot economy]] has remained stagnant and undeveloped because of the economic [[embargo]]es which have been imposed on the north.{{Harvnb|Tocci|2004|loc=61}}. Turkish Cypriots are still forced to emigrate, as a result of unemployment, and economic, social and moral degradation. Furthermore, due to the 'Turkeyfication' policies administered in the north, Turkish Cypriots responses to such policies of nationalisation have been to leave the island and moved to [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[Australia]], and [[Canada]].{{Harvnb|Papadakis|Peristianis|Welz|2006|loc=94}}. == Demographics == According to the [[Canada 2006 Census]], there were 43,700 Turks living in Canada; the majority were concentrated in [[Toronto]] (14,970), [[Montreal]] (10,345), [[Vancouver]] (3,380), [[Ottawa]] (2,455), [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]] (1,590), [[Calgary]] (1,305), and [[Edmonton]] (1,250).{{cite web |author=Statistics Canada|title=2006 Census|url=http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/topics/RetrieveProductTable.cfm?ALEVEL=3&APATH=3&CATNO=&DETAIL=0&DIM=&DS=99&FL=0&FREE=0&GAL=0&GC=99&GK=NA&GRP=1&IPS=&METH=0&ORDER=1&PID=92333&PTYPE=88971&RL=0&S=1&ShowAll=No&StartRow=1&SUB=801&Temporal=2006&Theme=80&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF=&GID=837928 |accessdate=25 February 2009}} However, the actual number of Turkish Canadians is believed to be considerably higher, as ethnic Turks have also immigrated to Canada via [[Bulgaria]], [[Cyprus]], and the [[Republic of Macedonia]]. Statistics on [[Bulgarian Turks]], [[Turkish Cypriots]], and [[Macedonian Turks]] present particular problems because it is unclear how many have immigrated to Canada; they are recorded by their citizenship (i.e. "Bulgarian", "Cypriot", and "Macedonian") rather than their ethnicity. ===Turkish settlement=== {| class="wikitable" |+ ! Percentage increase/decrease |- | 1 || {{ON}} || 14,580 || 23,425 || > 62% |- | 2 || {{QC}} || 5,680 || 11,390 || > 49.8% |- | 3 || {{BC}} || 2,395 || 4,250 || > 56.35% |- | 4 || {{AB}} || 1,515 || 2,970 || > 51% |- | 5 || {{NS}} || 190 || 425 || > 44.7% |- | 6 || {{SK}} || 105 || 400 || > 26.25% |- | 7 || {{MB}} || 275 || 345 || > 79% |- | 8 || {{NB}} || 125 || 275 || > 45% |- | 9 || {{NL}} || 35 || 135 || > 25.9% |- | 10 || {{NT}} || 10 || 65 || > 15% |- | 11 || {{YT}} || 0 || 10 || ≠ 0% |- | 12 || {{NU}} || 0 (10 Multiple responses) || 0 || ≠ 0% |- | 13 || {{PE}} || 0 || 0 || ≠ 0% |- | Total || '''{{flagcountry|Canada}}''' || '''24,910''' || '''43,700''' || '''> 57%''' |- |colspan=5|(Source: 2001 & 2006 Canadian Census') |} ==Culture== ===Religion=== The vast majority of Turkish Canadians are [[Sunni Muslims]], whilst the remaining people generally do not have any religious affiliation. Prior to 1980, Turkish Canadian immigrants were from both [[urban area|urban]] and [[secular]] backgrounds.{{Harvnb|Aksan|1999|loc=1279}} Religion remained an affair of the private conscience. In May 1983, the Canadian Turkish Islamic Heritage Association (Kanada Türk Islam Kültür Derneği) was established, followed by the Canadian Turkish Islamic Trust (Kanada Türk Islam Vakfi) in April 1987. ===Festivals=== *[[The Toronto Turkish Festival]] *The Calgary Turkish Festival *The Edmonton Turkish Festival *The Ottawa Turkish Festival[http://www.ottawaturkishfestival.com/ The Ottawa Turkish Festival] == Media == === Social media === * Turkish Association of Canada (TAC){{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/TurkishCanada|title=Security Check Required|website=Facebook.com|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * TurkKanada{{cite web|url=http://www.turkkanada.com|title=Turk Kanada - Kanada hakkında bilmeniz gereken herşey|website=Turk Kanada|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Anatolianheritagefoundation/{{cite web|url=http://www.anatolianheritage.ca|title=Turk Kanada - Kanada hakkında bilmeniz gereken herşey|website=Turk Kanada|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Intercultural Dialogue Institute{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.interculturaldialog.com| title=Turk Kanada - Kanada hakkında bilmeniz gereken herşey|website=Turk Kanada|accessdate=20 August 2017}} === Turkish newspapers === * ''Canadaturk''{{cite web|url=http://www.canadaturk.ca|title=Main Page|website=Canadaturk.ca|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * ''Referans'' * ''Idinews''{{cite web|url=http://edmonton.interculturaldialog.com|title=Edmonton Intercultural Dialogue Institute - IDI Edmonton|website=Edmonton.interculturaldialog.com}} * ''Bizim Anadolu''{{cite web|url=http://www.bizimanadolu.com/|title=Bizim Anadolu|website=Bizimanasdolu.com|accessdate=20 August 2017}} == Sports == * Atak Sports - Zafer Biryol Soccer Academy{{cite web|url=http://www.ataksports.com|title=ataksports.com|website=Ataksports.com|accessdate=20 August 2017}} == Education == Since 2005, [[Nile Academy]], a private school{{Cite web|title = Nile Academy|url = http://nileacademy.ca/|website = nileacademy.ca|access-date = 23 February 2016}} run by Turkish administration linked to a nonprofit organization called [[Canadian Turkish Friendship Community]],{{Cite web|title = Job Offers - Nile Academy BlueHaven|url = http://nileacademy.ca/bluehaven/job-offers/|website = nileacademy.ca|access-date = 23 February 2016}} has grown exponentially over the years. Within eleven years, they managed to open their 3rd{{Cite web|url = http://nileacademy.ca/plunkett/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Awards2013.pdf|title = Nile Academy 2013 Awards (PDF)|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} school within Ontario. They have also opened a dormitory located near Jane Street and Eglinton Avenue West, Toronto. Throughout the years, [[Nile Academy]] has competed in [[Turkish Language Olympiads]] and many wrestling tournaments in Ontario.{{Cite web|title = Nile Academy, Plunkett’s Wrestling Team - Nile Academy-Plunkett Campus|url = http://nileacademy.ca/plunkett/nile-academy-plunketts-wrestling-team/|website = nileacademy.ca|access-date = 23 February 2016}} Nile Academy is also linked with religious cleric and right-wing scholar [[Fethullah Gülen]] and the [[Gülen movement|Gülen Movement]].{{Cite web|title = Fethullah Gülen Web Sitesi - Kanada'daki Türk Okulundan Büyük Başarı|url = http://tr.fgulen.com/content/view/17682/11/|website = tr.fgulen.com|access-date = 23 February 2016}} They have had many notable alumni{{Cite web|title = Alumni - Nile Academy-Plunkett Campus|url = http://nileacademy.ca/plunkett/university-results/|website = nileacademy.ca|access-date = 23 February 2016}} since they opened in 2005. ==Associations== Since the 1960s, many community organizations have appeared representing various groups of [[Turkish people|Turkish]] immigrants. The various associations across [[Canada]] are currently represented by the "Federation of Canadian Turkish Associations", an umbrella organization founded in the mid-1980s.{{Harvnb|Aksan|1999|loc=1278}} The federation serves as a referral and communications centre for news of [[Turkey]], local events, business and governmental inquiries, and intergroup relations. More recently, a similar Turkish Cypriot umbrella group, the "Federation of Turkish Cypriot Associations of Canada", was established; the "Canadian Association for Solidarity of Turks from Bulgaria" also forms part of the federation. The Federation of Canadian Turkish Associations is an umbrella organization representing 17 member associations from Victoria to Quebec, which include approximately 50,000 Canadians of Turkish origin. The federation was established in 1985 and is a non-profit organization with no political affiliations. It supports and encourages activities that deal with important cultural, economic, educational, historical, social and religious issues that relate to the Turkish community in Canada. * Anatolian Heritage Federation{{cite web|url=http://anatolianheritage.ca/|title=Anatolian Heritage Federation Canada|website=Anatolianheritage.ca|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Ankara Library{{cite web|url=http://www.ankarakitapligi.ca/|title=ANKARA KITAPLIGI|website=Ankarakitapligi.ca|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Association of Balkan Canadians{{cite web |url=http://www.balkancanadian.org/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122031509/http://www.balkancanadian.org/ |archivedate=22 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }} * Association of Canadian Turkish Cypriots * Canadian Alevi Culture Centre{{cite web|url=http://www.kanadaalevi.com/|title=Kanada Alevi Kültür Merkezi|website=Kanadaalevi.com|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Canadian Association for Solidarity of Turks from Bulgaria * Canadian Iraqi Turkmen Culture Association of London * Canadian Turkish Cultural Association of Hamilton * Canadian Turkish Film Society * Canadian Turkish Islamic Heritage Association INC.{{cite web|url=http://www.papecami.com/|title=Kanada Türk İslam Kültür Derneği & Pape Cami - Turkish Canadian Cultural Association|website=Turk.ca|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Turkish Canadian Cultural Association of Calgary{{cite web|url=http://calgaryturkishcanadian.org/|title=Turkish Canadian Cultural Association of Calgary|website=calgaryturkishcanadian.org|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Turkish Canadian Society{{cite web|url=http://www.turkishcanadiansociety.org/|title=new homepage|website=Trukishcanadiansociety.org|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Turkish Canadian Society of Edmonton{{cite web |url=http://www.edmontonturks.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509062048/http://edmontonturks.com/ |archivedate=9 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }} * Turkish Canadian Society of Vancouver * The Turkish Community Heritage Centre of Canada{{cite web|url=http://www.turkishcommunitycentre.org/|title=TCHCC Home|website=Turkishcommunitycentre.org|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Turkish Federation Community Foundation{{cite web |url=http://vakif.turkishfederation.ca/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140523004143/http://vakif.turkishfederation.ca/ |archivedate=23 May 2014 |df=dmy-all }} * Turkish Culture and Folklore Society{{cite web |url=http://www.turkculture.ca/indexeng.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207143445/http://turkculture.ca/indexeng.html |archivedate=7 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }} * The Turkish Quebec Cultural and Friendship Association{{cite web |url=http://www.turquebec.ca/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415141956/http://www.turquebec.ca/ |archivedate=15 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }} * Turkish Society of Canada{{cite web|url=http://www.turkishcanada.org|title=Turkish Society of Canada - Turkish Society of Canada|date=15 March 2014|website=Turkishcanada.org|accessdate=20 August 2017}} * Turkish Society of Nova Scotia{{cite web |url=http://nsturkishsociety.ca/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704110939/http://nsturkishsociety.ca/ |archivedate=4 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }} * The United Canadian Muslim Association * United Canadian Turkish Cultural Association == Notable people == {{see also|List of Turkish Canadians}} == See also == {{Portal|Canada|Turkey}} *[[Canada–Turkey relations]] *[[Canadians in Turkey]] *[[Embassy of Turkey in Ottawa]] *[[Kurdish Canadians]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Bibliography == {{refbegin}} * {{citation |last=Abu-Laban|first=Baha|year=1983|chapter=The Canadian Muslim Community: The Need for a New Survival Strategy|title=The Muslim Community in North America|editor1-last=Waugh|editor1-first=Earle H.|editor2-last=Abu-Laban|editor2-first=Baha|editor3-last=Abu-Qureshi|editor3-first=Regula (eds.)|place=|publisher=University of Alberta|isbn=0-88864-034-X}}. * {{citation |last=Aksan|first=Virginia H.|year=1999|chapter=Turks|title=Encyclopedia of Canada's Peoples|editor1-last=Magocsi|url=http://multiculturalcanada.ca/Encyclopedia/A-Z/t6|editor1-first=Paul R. '''Vereinigung für Ökologische Ökonomie (VÖÖ)''' is a [[Germany|German]] scientific society promoting ecological principles in the global economy.
== History and background ==
In 1992, the economist [[Christiane Busch-Lüty]] and the physicist [[Hans-Peter Dürr]] gave a joint talk at a conference of [[Verein für Socialpolitik]] (VfS) on the topic of “economics and nature”.<ref name="cblhpd">{{citation/core|Surname1=[[Christiane Busch-Lüty]]|Surname2=[[Hans-Peter Dürr]]|EditorSurname1=Heinz König|Periodical=Umweltverträgliches Wirtschaften als Problem von Wissenschaft und Politik|Title=Ökonomie und Natur: Versuch einer Annäherung im interdisziplinären Dialog |Publisher=Duncker & Humblot|PublicationPlace=Berlin|Year=1993|At=pp. 13–44|ISBN=3-428-07771-7|Date= 1993|language=German|AccessDate=2015-02-03}}. See also the [http://www.voeoe.de/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Busch-Luety_Duerr_1992_Oekonomie-und-Natur_VfS.pdf online version (PDF)] and the preliminary remark.</ref> During the discussion, it turned out that the point of view presented had no backing among the attendees of VfS, and Busch-Lüty and colleagues decided to establish an independent society.<ref name="cblhpd"/> Busch-Lüty initiated in 1996 the establishment of VÖÖ as part of a small, [[Interdisciplinarity|interdisciplinary]] group of scientists as a German-speaking section of [[International Society for Ecological Economics]] (ISEE).<ref>''[http://www.oekologisches-wirtschaften.de/index.php/oew/article/download/790/790 Gründung einer Vereinigung für Ökologische Ökonomie im deutschsprachigen Raum: Call for Members].'' In: Ökologisches Wirtschaften, 1/1996. Accessed February 25, 2015</ref> The local mayor and former [[Member of the European Parliament]] [[Beate Weber]] acted as a [[patronage|patron]] of the constitutive conference in April 1996 in [[Heidelberg]]. The 50 scientists present shared the belief that the calls of [[Earth Summit|Rio Earth Summit 1992]] for establishing a [[sustainable development]] are legitimate and need to be realized.<ref name="leitbild">VÖÖ: [http://www.voeoe.de/die-voo/ Wir über uns, Leitbild], accessed February 25, 2015.</ref> Based on the insight that [[economic growth]] would be the wrong answer to persistent ecological problems, the scientists wanted to act strategically to alter the academic landscape.<ref>{{citation/core|Surname1=Arne Daniels|Periodical=[[Die Zeit]]|Issue=18|Year=1996|Date= 1996|language=German|URL=http://www.zeit.de/1996/18/Teleunternehmen_Amerikanische_Hochzeit_Brauereien_Schwaebische_Allianz_Eurotunnel_Franzoesisch-briti/seite-2|Format= Online}}</ref>
== Positions == The society argues that the economic sciences are overcharged with the necessary transformation and claims, that other scientific fields, politics open to change and the cultural forces of the society as a whole are necessary to implement and shape the change assumed necessary.<ref name="leitbild" /> Since the beginning, VÖÖ emphasized the necessity of a [[Transdisciplinarity|transdisciplinary]] approach.<ref>{{citation/core|Surname1=Peter Finke|EditorSurname1=Vereinigung für Ökologische Ökonomie e.V.|EditorSurname2=Irmi Seidl|Periodical=Ökologische Ökonomie: Ansätze zur Positionsbestimmung der Vereinigung für Ökologische Ökonomie|Title=Transdisziplinarität und Methodologie |Year=1999|At=pp. 6–16|Date= 1999|language=German}}. [http://www.voeoe.de/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/voeoe-1-1999-oekologische-oekonomie.pdf Online access (PDF)]</ref> Until 2010, VÖÖ was involved with establishing the concept of [[sustainability]] in its ecological, social and economic perspective.<ref name="finke">Peter Finke: [http://www.voeoe2010.uni-freiburg.de/Dateien/peter-finke_-die-voeoe-am-scheideweg.pdf Die VÖÖ am Scheideweg] (PDF; 23 kB), accessed February 25, 2015.</ref> Following a reorientation in 2010, the society promotes a [[post-growth]] economy based on the concepts of [[Niko Paech]] and others.<ref name="leitbild" /> The concept of [[sustainable growth]] is considered to be an [[oxymoron]],<ref name="finke" /> and the importance of [[eco-efficiency]], consistency and [[eco-sufficiency]] is emphasized.
== Activities == [[File:Boris woynowski voeoe jahrestagung 2012 podiumsdiskussion.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|Panel discussion at annual conference 2012]]
VÖÖ is working in research groups and organizes annual conferences,<ref name="tagung">[http://www.voeoe.de/aktivitaten/tagungen/ VÖÖ: Tagungen], accessed February 25, 2015.</ref> workshops und releases [[publication]]s such as a series of [[working paper|discussion papers]]<ref>[http://www.voeoe.de/publikationen/discussion/ VÖÖ Discussion Papers], ISSN [http://dispatch.opac.d-nb.de/DB=1.1/CMD?ACT=SRCHA&IKT=8&TRM=2366-7753 2366-7753], available at [https://www.econstor.eu/escollectionhome/10419/144744 econstor.eu].</ref> and books.<ref>Corinna Burkhart: ''Who says what is absurd? A case study on being(s) in an alternative normality''. Vereinigung für Ökologische Ökonomie e.V., Heidelberg 2015, {{ISBN|978-3-9811006-4-8}} ([http://www.voeoe.de/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/burkhart-who-says-what-is-absurd-2015.pdf PDF, 1.1 MB]).</ref><ref>Dirk Posse: ''Zukunftsfähige Unternehmen in einer Postwachstumsgesellschaft. Eine theoretische und empirische Untersuchung''. Vereinigung für Ökologische Ökonomie e.V., Heidelberg 2015, {{ISBN|978-3-9811006-2-4}} ([http://www.voeoe.de/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/posse-unternehmen-postwachstumsgesellschaft-2015.pdf PDF, 1 MB]).</ref><ref>[http://www.voeoe.de/aktivitaten/publikationen/ Veröffentlichungen der VÖÖ], accessed February 25, 2015.</ref> From October 2010 on, VÖÖ supports students and practitioners via the ''Netzwerk Wachstumswende''.<ref>[http://www.voeoe.de/kooperationen/netzwerk-wachstumswende/ Netzwerk Wachstumswende], accessed February 25, 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.wachstumswende.de Netzwerk Wachstumswende], accessed February 25, 2015.</ref>
Besides the presidents<ref name=vorstand>[http://www.voeoe.de/die-voo/der-vorstand/ Vorstand der VÖÖ], accessed November 15, 2016.</ref> Dirk Löhr and Susanne Hartard, other members of the board are [[Eva Lang]], [[Gerhard Oesten]] and [[Gerhard Scherhorn]]. Well known members are [[Adelheid Biesecker]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080326194359/http://www.nachhaltigkeit-neu-denken.de/referent/biesecker.htm Adelheid Biesecker at nachhaltigkeit-neu-denken.de], archived at [[Internet Archive]] on March 26, 2008.</ref> [[Hans Christoph Binswanger]],<ref name="cblhpd"/> [[Peter Finke]], [[Niko Paech]],<ref name="vorstand12-14">[http://www.voeoe.de/die-voo/der-vorstand/der-vorstand-2012-2014/ Der Vorstand 2012–2014], voeoe.de, accessed November 15, 2016.</ref> and [[Beate Weber]],<ref>[http://beate-weber.de/person/ beate-weber.de], accessed February 25, 2015.</ref> [[Hans-Peter Dürr]]<ref>[http://www.voeoe.de/2014/05/hans-peter-durr-7-10-1929-18-05-2014/ Hans-Peter Dürr, 7.10.1929 – 18.05.2014], voeoe.de, accessed February 25, 2015.</ref> was a founder member. [[Christiane Busch-Lüty]] who deceased November 2010 was honorary chairwoman of the society.<ref>[http://www.voeoe.de/die-voo/christiane-busch-luty/ Christiane Busch-Lüty], voeoe.de, accessed February 25, 2015.</ref>
== Research prizes == Between 1998 and 2002, VÖÖ granted together with [[Schweisfurth-Stiftung]] the biennal Schweisfurth-Forschungspreis für Ökologische Ökonomie, a research prize for contributions in the field of ecological economics. Laureates were Christa Müller, Ralf Weiß, Sigrid Stagl, [[Daniel Dahm]] and Stefanie Böge.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20040721024349/http://www.voeoe.de/inhalte/preis.html Aktivitäten: Forschungspreis]. In: voeoe.de, archived at [[Internet Archive]] on July 21, 2004.</ref><ref>[http://www.voeoe.de/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/276ecfe4a752efa1a3eee08324eae8cc09847333_CBL_Essay.pdf Weshalb der Nachhaltigkeitsdiskurs in Deutschland eine „Mutter“ hat...] (PDF; 389 kB), essay on [[Christiane Busch-Lüty]], oekom, page 3.</ref> Since 2004, VÖÖ grants together with several charitable foundations the biennal Kapp-Forschungspreis für Ökologische Ökonomie im remembrance of [[Karl William Kapp]].<ref name="kapp">[http://www.voeoe.de/aktivitaten/kapp-forschungspreis/ Kapp-Forschungspreis]. In: voeoe.de, accessed February 25, 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.kwilliam-kapp.de/ Karl Wilhelm Kapp], accessed February 25, 2015.</ref> Laureates were [[Michael Flitner]] and [[Dagmar Vinz]] (2004), [[Niko Paech]] and [[Bianca Borowski]] (2006), Fabian Scholtes and Eva Koch (2008), Lasse Loft and Oliver Stengel (2010), Gerolf Hanke and Anja Humburg (2012), Matthias Schmelzer, Corinna Burkhart and Dirk Posse (2014) as well as Lorenz Stör, Christian Arndt and Johannes Buhl (2016).<ref name="kapp"/> Since 2013, VÖÖ grants in remembrance of its honorary chairwoman the Christiane Busch-Lüty Förderpreis für Ökologische Ökonomie. Laureates were the sociologist Daniela Gottschlich (2013) and Tilman Santarius (2015).<ref>[http://www.voeoe.de/aktivitaten/christiane-busch-luty-forderpreis/ Christiane Busch-Lüty Förderpreis für Ökologische Ökonomie]. In: voeoe.de, accessed February 25, 2015.</ref><ref>Hohe Ehre für die Lüneburger Soziologin Daniela Gottschlich. In: [[Landeszeitung für die Lüneburger Heide]], September 14, 2013.</ref>
